case_title: Changaiz Khan and others vs The State and others
reference_no_or_id: Criminal Appeals Nos. 153, 156 of 2024 and Murder Reference No. 04 of 2024
complaint_summary: FIR No. 184 of 2006 was lodged by Ghulam Nabi alleging that the accused attacked him and his sons, resulting in the deaths of Zahoor Ahmed and Munir Ahmed and injuries to Shabbir Ahmed and Mir Ahmed.
investigation_summary: Police conducted investigations, collected evidence including bloodstained clothes and site sketches, and submitted challans. Statements of witnesses were recorded belatedly, raising doubts about the prosecution's case.
judgment_summary: The Balochistan High Court acquitted the appellants due to procedural irregularities, contradictions in witness testimonies, and failure of the prosecution to prove its case beyond reasonable doubt.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeals allowed; appellants acquitted; Murder Reference answered in negative.
legal_arguments: Delay in recording witness statements under Section 161, Cr.P.C.
Contradictions in testimonies of prosecution witnesses.
Failure to prove common intention under Section 149, P.P.C.
Non-production of key evidence such as recovery memos.

witness_statement.Bilal Ahmed: Eye-witness; shifted injured and deceased to hospital.
witness_statement.Dr. Ali Mardan: Produced medical certificates of injured and deceased.
witness_statement.Muhammad Rasheed: First Investigating Officer; produced FIR and site sketch.
witness_statement.Abid Gohram: Second Investigating Officer; produced supplementary challans.
witness_statement.Mustafa Hussain: Last Investigating Officer; produced incomplete challan.

maxims.Benefit of doubt: Even a single circumstance creating reasonable doubt entitles the accused to acquittal.

legal_terms.Ta'zir: Punishment under Islamic law for offenses not fixed by the Quran or Hadith.
legal_terms.Daman: Compensation for injuries under Islamic law.

words_and_phrases.Common intention: Pre-concert or pre-arrangement to commit a crime.
words_and_phrases.Constructive liability: Liability for acts committed by others in an unlawful assembly.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved allegations of murder and attempted murder stemming from a personal dispute. The trial court convicted the appellants, but the High Court acquitted them due to procedural flaws, contradictions in evidence, and failure to prove common intention.
case_number: Criminal Appeals Nos. 153, 156 of 2024 and Murder Reference No. 04 of 2024

convictions.compensation: Rs.400,000 each to legal heirs of deceased

incident_details.cause: Dispute over loitering near complainant's house

key_findings: Delay in FIR registration (1 hour 40 minutes)
Delay in recording witness statements under Section 161 Cr.P.C.
Contradictions in witness testimonies and site map
Failure to exhibit key evidence (e.g., fard-e-bayan, recovery memos)
No specific role assigned to certain appellants
Prosecution failed to prove common intention or motive
legal_principles: Benefit of doubt must go to accused (Muhammad Shah v. The State, 2010 SCMR 1009)
Credibility of witnesses questioned due to delayed statements (Muhammad Khan v. Moula Bakhsh, 1998 SCMR 570)
Withholding best evidence creates presumption against prosecution (Article 129(g), Qanun-e-Shahadat Order, 1984)
